case_vignette: A 1-year-old boy presents with a single, L-shaped, yellow-orange hairless patch over the left preauricular skin! The patient’s mother notes that he has never grown hair in that location! The mother is concerned because the area used to be smooth, but seems to be changing! The patient has a history of prematurity and low birthweight but is otherwise healthy! The patient has no relevant social or family history!
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a yellow-orange, hairless patch on the skin near my left ear that seems to be changing in texture.
How long have you noticed this patch, and has it been growing or changing in size?
I have never grown hair in that area since birth, and the patch itself has not been changing in size, but its texture seems to be changing.
Have you noticed any other symptoms such as pain, itching, or skin changes elsewhere on your body?
No, I haven't noticed any other symptoms like pain, itching, or changes in other areas of my skin.
Do you have any previous history of skin conditions, either personally or in your family?
No, I don't have a history of skin conditions personally or in my family.
Does the texture of the patch feel soft and velvety?
The texture of the patch seems to be changing, but it used to be smooth.
Final Diagnosis: Nevus sebaceus.
